greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to write n = x + y + z with y <= z such that 6*x-1, 6*y-1, 6*z-1 are terms of A230138 and 6*(y+z)+1 is prime.
comment: Conjecture: a(n) > 0 for all n > 2. Also, any integer n > 2 can be written as x + y + z (x, y, z > 0) such that 6*x-1, 6*y-1, 6*z-1 are terms of A230138 and 6*y*z-1 is prime.
This is a further refinement of the conjecture in A230140.
Note that if x + y + z = n then 6*n = (6*x-1) + (6*(y+z)+1). So a(n) > 0 implies Goldbach's conjecture for the even number 6*n.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Zhi-Wei Sun, <a href="http://arxiv.org/abs/1211.1588">Conjectures involving primes and quadratic forms, preprint, arXiv:1211.1588.
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Oct 10 2013
